articles.headline: Getting Back to Even
articles.snippet: Since the downturn began in December 2007, the economy has had a net decline of about 1 percent in its nonfarm payroll jobs.
articles.abstract: Since the downturn began in December 2007, the economy has had a net decline of about 1 percent in its nonfarm payroll jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the 38th consecutive month, the country added jobs: 203,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in November, to be more precise.

articles.headline: Health Care Law Providing Relief and Frustration
articles.snippet: The anxiety and the promise of revamping the health insurance system have left thousands of people in North Carolina struggling to sort out their options.
articles.abstract: The anxiety and the promise of revamping the health insurance system have left thousands of people in North Carolina struggling to sort out their options.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mike Horrigan is a lifelong Democrat with heart problems who supports President Obama’s health care law because he expects it will help many people obtain better insurance, including himself.
articles.byline: By John Schwartz and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Record Prices Mask a Tepid Market for Fine Art
articles.snippet: Analysts said recent headline-grabbing auction sales reflected the tastes of hedge fund billionaires, not a developing boom in the market for fine art.
articles.abstract: Analysts said recent headline-grabbing auction sales reflected the tastes of hedge fund billionaires, not a developing boom in the market for fine art.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, a triptych portrait by the British modernist painter Francis Bacon sold for $142.4 million, a record for a work of art at auction. The next night, a silk-screen print, “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster),” by the American pop artist Andy Warhol brought $105.4 million. And this week, “Saying Grace,” by the American illustrator Norman Rockwell, sold for $46.1 million.

articles.headline: Generation Born After Apartheid Sees Mandela’s Fight as History
articles.snippet: Those born after apartheid’s end say their determination to look to the future and not the past is the greatest tribute they can pay Nelson Mandela.
articles.abstract: Those born after apartheid’s end say their determination to look to the future and not the past is the greatest tribute they can pay Nelson Mandela.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Sitting in her comfortable suburban living room 45 minutes east of Johannesburg, Nokuthula Magubane, 18, was doing something close to unthinkable to older generations of black South Africans: She was affectionately praising Afrikaans.

articles.headline: Making a Difference in This Season of Giving
articles.snippet: An ethicist offers a guide on how much to donate, and other experts suggest where the money should go.
articles.abstract: An ethicist offers a guide on how much to donate, and other experts suggest where the money should go.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the holiday giving season in full swing, you may be re-evaluating just how much to give to charitable causes and where to donate.

articles.headline: An Assist for Weinstein’s ‘Mandela’
articles.snippet: Harvey Weinstein, a master at building buzz around his movies, walks a fine line in publicizing his new film, “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom.”
articles.abstract: Harvey Weinstein, a master at building buzz around his movies, walks a fine line in publicizing his new film, “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harvey Weinstein is a master at using publicity to build buzz around his movies, whether that means ginning up a controversy or concocting a cultural tie-in.

articles.headline: Pushed Out of a Job Early
articles.snippet: Age discrimination claims are on the rise as members of the post-World War II baby boom enter their 60s.
articles.abstract: Age discrimination claims are on the rise as members of the post-World War II baby boom enter their 60s.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is one thing older workers fear in this economy, it’s losing their jobs as they approach retirement. But that is exactly what happened in March to Richard L. White, who was the director of career services at Rutgers University for 22 years.

articles.headline: A Tricky Airline Merger, but With Labor’s Blessing
articles.snippet: As American Airlines and US Airways join to become the world’s largest airline, the new company will have to combine two carriers with vastly different operating cultures and backgrounds.
articles.abstract: As American Airlines and US Airways join to become the world’s largest airline, the new company will have to combine two carriers with vastly different operating cultures and backgrounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airline mergers are notoriously difficult to pull off, but when the deal between American Airlines and US Airways closes on Monday, the giant carrier can at least count on having employees on its side.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Pill to Treat Hepatitis C
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration has approved Sovaldi, from Gilead Sciences, which will let some patients be treated for a minimum of 12 weeks, but at a cost of $1,000 per daily pill.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has approved Sovaldi, from Gilead Sciences, which will let some patients be treated for a minimum of 12 weeks, but at a cost of $1,000 per daily pill.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a pill that is expected to make the treatment of hepatitis C less onerous, shorter in duration and more effective.

articles.headline: North Korea Says It Has Released Veteran It Held After Visit
articles.snippet: Merrill Newman did top-secret work as an Army intelligence officer during the Korean War. On a return visit to the North this fall, he was accused of war crimes and held, then released.
articles.abstract: Merrill Newman did top-secret work as an Army intelligence officer during the Korean War. On a return visit to the North this fall, he was accused of war crimes and held, then released.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Newman, 85, active retiree and intrepid traveler, preferred exotic places to popular ones. He had sailed around the world. He had been to Cuba and the Galápagos Islands. So it was not so odd when he decided that his next journey would be a return to North Korea, where 60 years ago he did top-secret work as a United States Army intelligence officer.
articles.byline: By Barry Bearak and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Disappointment in Successors to Nelson Mandela, a Revered Father of a Nation
articles.snippet: There has been a struggle to fill the shoes of Mr. Mandela and the other leaders of the South African liberation fight.
articles.abstract: There has been a struggle to fill the shoes of Mr. Mandela and the other leaders of the South African liberation fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: MVEZO, South Africa — Adam Bhasikile’s day begins at dawn, always in the same way. Flanked by donkeys, she walks to the valley floor, collecting water for the family to cook, clean and bathe from the Mbashe River, which snakes around this hilltop village like a winding moat. It is an unending ritual that Nelson Mandela’s mother, who gave birth to the future president here in 1918, almost certainly performed as well.

articles.headline: New York’s Junior Senator, Doggedly Refusing to Play the Part
articles.snippet: Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York has defied colleagues and stood her ground on issues, earning her prominence in a chamber in which she has served less than five years.
articles.abstract: Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York has defied colleagues and stood her ground on issues, earning her prominence in a chamber in which she has served less than five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there were a chutzpah caucus in the United States Senate, Kirsten Gillibrand of New York would be its natural leader.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Tracked Business Linked to China Hiring
articles.snippet: Confidential documents offer the most detailed account yet of JPMorgan’s “Sons and Daughters” hiring program, which has been at the center of a federal bribery investigation.
articles.abstract: Confidential documents offer the most detailed account yet of JPMorgan’s “Sons and Daughters” hiring program, which has been at the center of a federal bribery investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have obtained confidential documents that shed new light on JPMorgan Chase’s decision to hire the children of China’s ruling elite, securing emails that show how the bank linked one prominent hire to “existing and potential business opportunities” from a Chinese government-run company.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Wall Street Mothers, Stay-Home Fathers
articles.snippet: For growing numbers of women on Wall Street, stay-at-home husbands are enabling them to compete at work with new intensity.
articles.abstract: For growing numbers of women on Wall Street, stay-at-home husbands are enabling them to compete at work with new intensity.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Husbands Do Domestic Duty, These Women Are Free to Achieve
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Playing Pension Games
articles.snippet: As cities and states face shortfalls, there is a need for more disclosure, not less, about pension funds.
articles.abstract: As cities and states face shortfalls, there is a need for more disclosure, not less, about pension funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pity the municipal bondholder. Between Detroit’s bankruptcy and the rising concerns over unfunded pensions in Illinois and elsewhere, it has been a rough year for many muni bond investors. While the Standard & Poor’s municipal bond index has recovered from its September lows, it is still off 2.7 percent for the year.

articles.headline: In Mass Attacks, New Advice Lets Medics Rush In
articles.snippet: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has released guidelines on mass casualty events for first responders, recommending entry into “warm zones” before they are secured.
articles.abstract: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has released guidelines on mass casualty events for first responders, recommending entry into “warm zones” before they are secured.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seven minutes after the authorities in Sparks, Nev., received a call one day in October that a gunman was on the loose at a local middle school, a paramedic wearing a bulletproof vest and a helmet arrived at the scene.

articles.headline: Britain’s Ministry of Nudges
articles.snippet: Inspired by American behavioral economics, the British government is finding new ways to gently prod people to pay taxes, find jobs and insulate their homes.
articles.abstract: Inspired by American behavioral economics, the British government is finding new ways to gently prod people to pay taxes, find jobs and insulate their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alex Gyani had an idea, but even he considered it a little far-fetched.

articles.headline: Madoff Victims, Five Years the Wiser
articles.snippet: Speaking from experience, victims of the Madoff Ponzi scheme advise other investors to diversify their savings, focus on what really matters in life and resist giving up.
articles.abstract: Speaking from experience, victims of the Madoff Ponzi scheme advise other investors to diversify their savings, focus on what really matters in life and resist giving up.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the first global Ponzi scheme — a slow-motion crime wave that began in the Manhattan offices of a stockbroker named Bernard L. Madoff, spread to wealthy enclaves in Palm Beach, Fla., and Southern California, and reached as far as the Persian Gulf. It carried a breathtaking price: $64.8 billion in paper wealth and at least $17.5 billion in cash losses. Those affected ranged from carpenter-union pensioners to French aristocrats.

articles.headline: In Nation Remade by Mandela, Social Equality Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: Black South Africans are still very far behind whites when it comes to income and education, and by some measures falling further back.
articles.abstract: Black South Africans are still very far behind whites when it comes to income and education, and by some measures falling further back.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — When Freddy Kenny started his business selling vegetables out of a battered pickup truck in the 1970s, a siren used to sound over this city, his hometown, every night at 9, signaling to him and every other black person that they must leave the city limits immediately or face arrest.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Marcus Mabry

articles.headline: Protesters in Kiev Topple Lenin Statue as Rallies Grow
articles.snippet: Protests in Ukraine’s capital, which have grown for two weeks and seemed to reach new heights Sunday, show the depth of rage at Ukraine’s president, who has few palatable options to defuse the country’s crisis.
articles.abstract: Protests in Ukraine’s capital, which have grown for two weeks and seemed to reach new heights Sunday, show the depth of rage at Ukraine’s president, who has few palatable options to defuse the country’s crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Public protests thundered into a full-throttle civil uprising in Ukraine on Sunday, as hundreds of thousands of protesters answered President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s dismissiveness with their biggest rally so far, demanding that he and his government resign.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Fed’s Plan to Taper Stimulus Effort Is Not Expected Until Next Year
articles.snippet: Significant details of the eventual retreat also remain the subjects of unresolved debates, according to public statements by Fed officials and interviews with some of them.
articles.abstract: Significant details of the eventual retreat also remain the subjects of unresolved debates, according to public statements by Fed officials and interviews with some of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are in no hurry to retreat from their bond-buying campaign to stimulate the economy and are likely to postpone any cuts to the program until next year, according to public statements by Fed officials and interviews with some of them.

articles.headline: In Shepherding Detroit Bankruptcy, Lawyer Tackles a Job He Didn’t Ask For
articles.snippet: Kevyn D. Orr, Detroit’s emergency manager, has faced criticism from those who dislike his proposals for mending the city’s finances, including possibly cutting pensions.
articles.abstract: Kevyn D. Orr, Detroit’s emergency manager, has faced criticism from those who dislike his proposals for mending the city’s finances, including possibly cutting pensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Kevyn D. Orr, the man who must now revive Detroit, commutes each week from Maryland to a cavernous old office building here that seems to dare him to succeed: the former headquarters of a company, itself recently in bankruptcy, that once sold more than half of America’s cars — General Motors.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Near a Vote, Volcker Rule Is Weathering New Attacks
articles.snippet: Five regulatory agencies are to vote Tuesday on the rule, which has met with thinly veiled threats of challenges from banks and business trade groups.
articles.abstract: Five regulatory agencies are to vote Tuesday on the rule, which has met with thinly veiled threats of challenges from banks and business trade groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as five regulatory agencies prepared to vote Tuesday on a regulation that seeks to rein in risk-taking on Wall Street — an effort known as the Volcker Rule — lawyers and lobbyists were gearing up for another round of attacks against it.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Where Freedom of the Press Is Muffled
articles.snippet: China and Britain both underscore how transparency, however painful in the moment, allows democracy, business and the citizenry to thrive in the long run.
articles.abstract: China and Britain both underscore how transparency, however painful in the moment, allows democracy, business and the citizenry to thrive in the long run.
articles.lead_paragraph: In China on Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke plainly about the role of a free press in a democratic society.

articles.headline: Three Senators Try to Hold Off G.O.P. in South
articles.snippet: Three Democrats facing tough re-election fights next year are essentially all that stand between Republicans and complete control of the old Confederacy’s Senate delegation.
articles.abstract: Three Democrats facing tough re-election fights next year are essentially all that stand between Republicans and complete control of the old Confederacy’s Senate delegation.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Things traditionally get started a little late down here, an inclination that runs from mealtimes to political races. But with nearly a year to go before the 2014 election, it is already open season on Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: The Gofer’s Expanding Portfolio
articles.snippet: The modern assistant has an understanding of social media that time-stretched (and old school) magazine executives lack, and increasingly they are assuming responsibility for spreading the magazine’s message.
articles.abstract: The modern assistant has an understanding of social media that time-stretched (and old school) magazine executives lack, and increasingly they are assuming responsibility for spreading the magazine’s message.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sergio Kletnoy was trapped in traffic and running behind schedule. As the executive assistant to Joanna Coles, the editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, Mr. Kletnoy had spent the day scheduling a December lunch for Ms. Coles, booking her business trip to Boston and accompanying her to Chelsea, where she made a speech before an online financial group while he held her purse. In a free moment, he had interviewed the singer Betty Who for Cosmopolitan’s blog and arranged for Ms. Coles to meet her as well.

articles.headline: Tech Giants Issue Call for Limits on Government Surveillance of Users
articles.snippet: Eight major companies, led by Google and Microsoft, are calling for tighter controls on surveillance of their customers’ data by governments worldwide.
articles.abstract: Eight major companies, led by Google and Microsoft, are calling for tighter controls on surveillance of their customers’ data by governments worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight prominent technology companies, bruised by revelations of government spying on their customers’ data and scrambling to repair the damage to their reputations, are mounting a public campaign to urge President Obama and Congress to set new limits on government surveillance.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Eastern States Press Midwest to Improve Air
articles.snippet: The governors of eight Northeastern states plan to petition the Environmental Protection Agency to force stricter air pollution rules on nine Rust Belt and Appalachian states.
articles.abstract: The governors of eight Northeastern states plan to petition the Environmental Protection Agency to force stricter air pollution rules on nine Rust Belt and Appalachian states.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a battle that pits the East Coast against the Midwest over the winds that carry dirty air from coal plants, the governors of eight Northeastern states plan to petition the Environmental Protection Agency on Monday to force tighter air pollution regulations on nine Rust Belt and Appalachian states.

articles.headline: Spies Infiltrate a Fantasy Realm of Online Games
articles.snippet: American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games, fearing that militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks, documents show.
articles.abstract: American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games, fearing that militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks, documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not limiting their activities to the earthly realm, American and British spies have infiltrated the fantasy worlds of World of Warcraft and Second Life, conducting surveillance and scooping up data in the online games played by millions of people across the globe, according to newly disclosed classified documents.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Justin Elliott

articles.headline: Public Ouster in North Korea Unsettles China
articles.snippet: As North Koreans watched the unusual spectacle of Jang Song-thaek’s arrest on television, Chinese leaders were concerned about the loss of one of their major links to the leadership of the North.
articles.abstract: As North Koreans watched the unusual spectacle of Jang Song-thaek’s arrest on television, Chinese leaders were concerned about the loss of one of their major links to the leadership of the North.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — North Koreans had long known Jang Song-thaek as the No. 2 figure in their country, the revered uncle and mentor of Kim Jong-un, the paramount leader. Then on Monday state-run television showed two green-uniformed guards clutching a glum-looking Mr. Jang by the armpits and pulling him from a meeting of the ruling party after he was denounced for faction-building, womanizing, gambling and other acts as dozens of former comrades watched.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Choe Sang-Hun
